body: pls show a fully copy-pastable MINIMAL example.

```python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from pandas import Series, DataFrame
df=DataFrame(np.arange(0,16).reshape(4,4),index=list('abcd'),columns=list('wxyz'))
print("Original table:")
print(df)
print("=========")
print("CASE 1(by column direction): Filter all by reference column:w if value bigger than 1 ... WORKING")
print("Checking mask series ... OK")
print(df.loc[:,'w']>1)
print("Checking result ... OK")
print(df.where(lambda x: x.loc[:,'w']>1))
print("=========")
print("CASE 2(by row/index direction): Filter all by reference index:a if value bigger than 1 ... NOT WORKING")
print("Checking mask series... OK")
print(df.loc['a',:]>1)
print("Checking result ... NOK")
print(df.where(lambda x: x.loc['a',:]>1, axis=1))
print(df.where(lambda x: x.loc['a',:]>1, axis=0))

print("=========")
# Expected Result:
print('''# Expected Result:
#NaN NaN  2  3
#NaN NaN  6  7
#NaN NaN 10 11
#NaN NaN 14 15
''')
print(pd.__version__)

```

I think this comes down to alignment of the mask's index with the original dataframe.

http://pandas-docs.github.io/pandas-docs-travis/indexing.html#the-where-method-and-masking discusses masking.
